author: Julietta Jameson
title: Iconic Hollywood hotel gets a facelift
text:
Iconic Hollywood hotel gets a facelift JULIETTA JAMESON Last updated 14:19, July 12 2015 Instagram / jfranks86 
The iconic Hotel Roosevelt is rumoured to be haunted occasionally by Marilyn Monroe and Charlie Chaplin. 
In a town known for famously awful facelifts, this one's a famous success. 
The iconic Hotel Roosevelt on Hollywood Boulevard in Los Angeles has recently undergone a US$25 million (NZ$37 million) renovation, accentuating the grand old dame's most attractive features. 
The redo is on the back of owners David Chang and Goodwin Gaw, taking over the management reigns "in order to further preserve the truly unique spirit of the hotel and give the undivided attention that only an in-house, independent management company may provide". The 1920s beauty had hit record room occupancy under the glam Thompson Hotels umbrella, but Chang and Gaw felt it needed to be a standalone, one-of-a-kind. 
Under the steerage of hip firm Yabu Pushelberg, the Roosevelt – rumoured to be haunted occasionally by Marilyn Monroe and Charlie Chaplin – now has a look that is much more bespoke and which harkens to its original Spanish colonial design notes. 
Subtle textures, beautiful leathers and soft, grey tones with persimmon-red accents feature throughout and there's a real sense of sumptuous comfort. 
The Hotel Roosevelt's new look draws on its original Spanish colonial design. 
Newly glammed up she may be, but the hotel, which was home to the very first Oscars ceremony, is still home for many in Hollywood. 
The Tropicana Cafe, Library Bar, the Spare Room bowling alley and other public spaces continue to be hives for entertainment industry heavyweights and wannabes. And the renowned Tropicana heated outdoor swimming pool, painted by acclaimed artist David Hockney, remains untouched. 
Like the hotel itself, it's designated a historic-cultural monument by the Los Angeles Cultural Heritage Commission.
